title: 113_hr5169
content: The "Senior Executive Service Accountability Act" requires biennial justification of positions and extends the probationary period for senior executives from 1 to 2 years. It also modifies pay retention for senior executives removed for underperformance. Section 3594(c)(1)(B) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to ensure career appointees placed under specific subsections are entitled to receive basic pay at certain rates. Career appointees placed under specific subsections are entitled to receive basic pay at the rate in effect for the position. SEC. 5 amends Section 4312(b)(1) of title 5, requiring performance requirements to be established not later than 30 calendar days and communicated in writing. SEC. 6 makes amendments to adverse action provisions for career appointees in the Senior Executive Service. The text amends Section 7501 of title 5, United States Code, defining 'employee' for Senior Executive Service employees and modifies cause and procedure for suspension and termination in Section 7543. The text amends Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code, regarding the modification of cause and procedure for suspension and termination in the Senior Executive Service. It allows for extensions of deadlines for employee answers and agency decisions by up to 30 days each. The text amends Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code, allowing for extensions of deadlines for employee answers and agency decisions by up to 30 days each. It also outlines the consequences for an employee subject to removal, including repayment of received pay and removal of accrued annual leave during the period of administrative leave. Additionally, there are conforming amendments made to Subchapter V of chapter 35 of title 5, United States Code, related to promoting efficiency of service and misconduct. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 16, 2014. Karen L. Haas attested to it.
